utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's Friday, and that means it's time for Friday Follies. The Democratic debate provided us with more ridiculous and hysterical moments that we ever could have imagined. Here with all the details, Raymond Arroyo, Fox News contributor. All right, Raymond, you noticed some trends during the debate, through lines that the audiences might have missed.

utterances.speaker: RAYMOND ARROYO, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: I did, Laura. The first thing that jumped out at me was the attempt to subtly lay claim to a favorite phrase of a former president as a way to build stature. If only they could have been clearer.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: First of all, let me be very clear.

utterances.speaker: YANG
utterances.utterance: Let me be clear.

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.utterance: Let's be clear. Let's be clear. Let's be clear about this.

utterances.speaker: BOOKER
utterances.utterance: Look, let's just be clear.

utterances.speaker: O'ROURKE
utterances.utterance: Two things became crystal clear for me.

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, D-CALIF., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Let me be very clear.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Versus let's be fuzzy right now. Obama always said that.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: He did indeed. As we'll remind you.

utterances.speaker: BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: So let me be clear. Let me be clear. Let me be clear. Now, let me be clear, let me be absolutely clear.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Joe Biden mentioned Obama so often, Laura, I thought he might be running for a third term. Listen.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: I know that the senator says she's for Bernie. Well, I'm for Barack. This president has done a great deal, so I'm proud to have served with him. Barack turned, the president turned to me and said, Joe, when they said we've got a plan to get out, he turned to the whole security and said, Joe will organize this.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Biden's PAC even released an ad, Laura, to reinforce the relationship in case you forgot.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: Barack Obama is an extraordinary man. I watched up close. He has character, courage, and vision. He was a great president. I was proud to serve as his vice president.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: But then something funny happened on stage, Laura. Biden couldn't recall who the president was.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: I hear this large saving. The president thinks, my friend from Vermont thinks the employer is going to give you back if you negotiate his union all these years.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: So he called Biden -- he called Sanders the president there. The poor man. My heart always breaks for him. He's so earnest. He's so wants this nomination.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. Wait a second. He's so earnest?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: He is earnest. He's earnest.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I kind of like Biden, I have to say.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: He wants it so badly. I just think the bloom is off the lily here.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That's like the glory days, the Springsteen song, has passed you by. Glory Days.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: There's a moment. There's a moment, yes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Things really went off of the rails for Biden when he started offering parenting advice to low-income kids.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: Play the radio. Make sure the television -- excuse me, make sure you have the record player on at night, the phone -- make sure the kids hear words.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Was that an answer to a question?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: This was a pivot from a question about reparations. And he was trying to get to his plan, which is a home visitation plan where people come in and help kids -- talk to them, give them language. So he was saying put the radio on --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Give them language?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: -- put something on so the kids pick up more words.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I'm here from the government, I'm here to raise your children. No thanks.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: It is part of the Affordable Care Act. Then there was Biden's unfortunate upper palate issue. Oh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Four months after Sandy Hook, a measure to require background checks died on the Senate floor. If you couldn't get it done after Sandy Hook, why should voters give you another chance?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: Because I've got it done before. I'm the only one up here that has ever beat the NRA.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Poor man, I hope Polident --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Poligrip, not Polident.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: -- or Poligrip are the next sponsors of the debate.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Poor guy.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Then there was Kamala Harris who looked like -- she was very relaxed.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I think she kind of had a cool way of -- it was kind of a cool - -

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: She has admitted to smoking weed.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Oh, she wasn't. We're joking. She looked --

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying she has admitted that in the past.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: She came across as very relaxed.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: Donald Trump in office on trade policy, he reminds me of that guy in "The Wizard of Oz," you know, when you pull back the curtain, it's a really small dude.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to take the bait, Senator Harris.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: That wasn't about you.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: I would say, hey, Joe, instead of saying no, we can't, let's say yes, we can.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: She was real laid back last night.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I thought she was pretty good.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: You thought kamala Harris was really good? Wait a minute, you jumped me for defending Joe Biden, earnest Joe Biden, and you're going to defend kamala Harris. She's all over, hey all right, Wizard of Oz, little dude.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I like that. I like that. It was like a slow roll. It was kind of calm.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: She's going to slow roll right off of that stage in the next debate with three other people standing there.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I didn't say she was going to win. Coming up, can a Hollywood actor survive after coming out as a Trump supporter? Former "Gray's Anatomy" star Isaiah Washington is here exclusively next to tell us next. You don't want to miss it.

utterances.speaker: ISAIAH WASHINGTON, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: I look at the political image of the Democratic Party over the last 50 years of my lifetime, since I was five and I'm 55. And very little has changed in my community, just two blocks over from where I am right now. I have some questions. I've got more than questions. Now I have evidence, I have empirical evidence that something is wrong.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That was former "Gray's Anatomy" star Isaiah Washington opening up after why he left the Democratic Party after visiting President Trump at the White House earlier this year. He is since come out as a Trump supporter, and he recently tweeted his message to fellow actors, saying "I have a message for Hollywood actors DM'ing me and revealing that you're conservatives. Don't DM me again because you all are lame and I don't respond well to hypocrites or cowards. You're no different from the bystander that is waiting on the blood to spill from a martyr." Joining me now exclusively is Isaiah Washington, host of the podcast "Isaiah Washington Speaks Again." He's also the author of a book, "A Man from Another Land." And he helped to create the new PAC Legacy Republicans. Isaiah, thanks for coming on tonight. We really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: ISAIAH WASHINGTON, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Laura. Thank you for having me.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So all these years later, you finally decided to come home to the Republican Party? Now, why did you leave the Democrat Party, explain it.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: I would be remiss, before we get into the weeds on that, I would be remiss if I don't bring up the fact that I don't watch much television. I'm an avid, arduous researcher. And since I have been put on the national conversation, I think I've been pretty much more in the midst of multiple ironies. I'm not the kind of person that's really fond of being categorized. For example, the irony that I got to Washington, D.C., on a Sunday, Nipsey Hussle was being murdered. And the irony is that I made a tweet on the 1st, April 1st, and then on April 2nd, Fox News decided to cherry-pick one of my tweets that implied that I was slamming 44 and supporting 45. Let me just make it perfectly clear. I am not one to be categorized. I'm not a Trump supporter, but I am a huge supporter of many people, over 60,000, that are Trump supporters. So what I mean by that, in the very fabric of my DNA, I have naturally been a protector and a liberator. I love this country. I'm a patriot. I'm former military. So I will say this. I supported the first step back. I supported 45. And that's why we're here.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That's awesome. Isaiah, I have a question for you. I spend quite a bit of time -- I know a bunch of big folks in Hollywood. And most of them are liberals, but they're actually pretty nice. They're always nice to me. And they don't like know -- anyone to know that they know me, I'm sure. But why is it that Hollywood, which prides itself on being so diverse, is so closed off to people who disagree on policy, or who vote a different way? Isn't that part of the diversity that everyone should embrace?

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: You know, I just turned 55 again this year.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Oh, good.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: August 3rd. So, I've lived through 11 presidents, and one I didn't quite remember. The only reason I knew who he was is because my grandmother had a velour towel or blanket on the wall that had Martin Luther King and Robert F. Kennedy and JFK. So I knew there was a lot of love and respect for that particular president. And as I grew older, I realized he was assassinated by what appeared to be our own government. Growing up through that, I've seen a lot of things that I don't necessarily agree with, but when I was in the military during the Reagan years, I made myself very, very vulnerable and risked my life for the Constitution. And I still feel that way. I'm still cut from that cloth. I am a person that is very mission-orientated. I strategize to get to Spike Lee, to get my career. I did it after I saw "She's Got to Have It" in 1986.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It was a hilarious movie, one of my favorite movies of all time. I love that movie. Oh, my gosh, hilarious.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: And what I learned out of that is that people are just people. Human beings are human beings. And what I learned in the 30 years of this business, people tend to abuse their power. And what I learned also, that people usually, liberals or anywhere, the private sector, military, and now Hollywood, hurt people, hurt people. It doesn't matter. If you were a jerk before you made millions and millions of dollars, you're going to be a jerk once you become successful.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But Isaiah, you were one of the biggest television stars in one of the biggest --

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: Who says I'm not?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, well --

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: Who says I'm not anymore? I know you have a habit of cutting people off. So I want to be clear. I've been on "The 100." I've been on "The 100" for Netflix for the last five years. I'm not a former "Gray's Anatomy." I went back, took 13 percent, made so much money that everybody got paid extra salaries. So let's not talk about former "Gray's Anatomy." Let's talk about former "The 100," which is trending on Netflix right now.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, we already know. You're already established.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: We have to deal in the now.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But not everybody watches Netflix, hate to tell you. Not everybody watches. But --

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: And not everybody watches -- not everybody watches FOX News, either, because I certainly don't.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: An iconic television show -- an iconic television show, and the show runner, Shonda Rhimes, one of the most brilliant television producers, writers. She actually went to my alma mater. She's a big Democrat. And you were kind of a -- kind of a Democrat then as well, right? So did you have a political mind meld when you worked on that show? Or was politics never even brought up?

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: I'll say this. I've been political since the day I was born. Any African-American man born black in America is political, particularly if you live over 50. So that just makes me political by the very nature of me just still being here to survive.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: The other part of that question is, I never talk politics. Shonda and I, no one, we never talked politics on that show.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Good, that's the way it should be.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: Yes, just to get to diversity. Remember, there was no Barack Obama before my character. I was the first dark-skinned African-American that really went into American homes. As a matter of fact I had to bring an actual heart surgeon who was African-American to the set because no one believed there was any black surgeons in America. So that was a long time ago, long time ago.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Isaiah, earlier, you said that the U.S. government assassinated MLK and JFK -- we can talk about that more. But is that -- that's what you believe in your heart of hearts? That's where you are on that?

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: Excuse me?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Did you say the government --

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: Is that what I --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You said the government assassinated two of our most historic figures?

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: You've got to be kidding. This is not a conspiracy theory. It's a fact. Everyone knows this.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: We've got to go, Isaiah.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: This is what got you in trouble with Nipsy Hussle.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. We got to go, Isaiah. That's cool. But we appreciate you joining us and we appreciate the fact that you took time tonight. Up next, the viral anti-AOC ad aired during the debate. Find out the controversy, next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Perhaps the most viral moment from last night's debate didn't happen on stage, but instead during one of the commercial breaks. Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: This is the face of socialism and ignorance. Does Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez know the horror of socialism? My father was minutes from death in Cambodia before a forced marriage saved his life. That's socialism.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The woman behind that anti-AOC socialism ad is Republican activist Elizabeth Heng, the daughter of Cambodian refugees who fled communism. AOC wasn't thrilled about the ad, as you can imagine. She tweeted in response, "Know that this wasn't an ad for young conservatives of color. That was the pretense. What you watched was a love letter to the GOP's white supremacist case." Here to respond is Elizabeth Heng, former congressional candidate and executive director of New Faces GOP PAC. All right, Elizabeth, well, AOC says this was a love letter to white supremacists. You don't look like a white supremacist. You are yourself are a minority. But does she have a point? Do you have to have her self-immolating in flames there?

utterances.speaker: ELIZABETH HENG, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, NEW FACES GOP
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to get in a debate, especially with the name calling, with a -- with a member of Congress. I put the ad on there because I wanted to have a real discussion about what true socialism is in this country, and have her defend the ideology which she continues to promote. Yet, instead of actually having a real policy debate, she insults me with name calling and a number of other areas.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Omar says it should be pulled from the air. Maybe you can reach out to her and see if she'll actually have a conversation with you, or maybe have some kind of forum on, I don't know, defending the tenets of socialism. But Ilhan Omar obviously very controversial herself rallying to the side of fellow squad member AOC here. So they're all rallying. Rashida Tlaib, all of them are coming to her defense. And this is after of course they all throw around the phrase "white supremacist" like it's nothing. As my mother used to say, they can dish it out, but they can't take it. They can dish out the worst pejorative about people because they disagree with them, but the moment you prick their little trial balloon, they start to scream foul. I'm not buying the damsel in distress routine from the squad.

utterances.speaker: HENG
utterances.utterance: And I couldn't agree with you more on that. So instead of defending the policy stances that they continue to push of these big socialist ideologies, they resort to throwing -- calling people racist and sexist and all these other things, instead of actually talking about what the real policy -- instead of actually talking about what and defending the arguments that they continue to have.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Elizabeth, do you think young people, though, really understand what you're trying to get at here with the evils of socialism? It's never worked. It's never worked around the world. Variants haven't, the real deal hasn't work. It's never worked. It has led to heart ache and the superrich and the super poor. It's never led to anything else.

utterances.speaker: HENG
utterances.utterance: Correct.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But the young people don't know that. They're not being taught that.

utterances.speaker: HENG
utterances.utterance: I agree. We're not learning it in our school systems. And they're getting information from different news sources. And so that's why I want to highlight this during the Democrat presidential debate in hopes that it would go viral so we could begin to educate young people and have a discussion of truly what this has done throughout the world, not just in Cambodia, but in Venezuela, in Cuba, North Korea, China, in Russia, because we're not learning this in our education system. And this is forcing discussion.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You got everybody's attention, that's for sure. Elizabeth, thanks for joining us. An age-defying Last Bite is next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You bet it's time for the Last Bite. A man believed to be the oldest living World War II vet celebrated his 110th birthday at the National World War II Museum in New Orleans yesterday. Here is Lawrence Brooks and his daughter Vanessa reflecting on the day.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I made it, and I'm glad to be here, I made it. So many things happened, some of them I remember, and some of them I don't. Some of them I want to remember, and some of them I don't want to remember.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Now that my dad is 100, I asked him, I said, daddy, how long you think you're going to live? He said to be 112, baby. So he has 12 more years left.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Wow, what a man. He said his secret to a long life is that he loves all people. He loves humanity. Amazing. That's all the time we have tonight.
